quizzes.question:
What is the output of this code?
>>> print('print("print")')
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Output[/h1]

Usually, programs take [b]input [/b]and process it to produce [b]output[/b].
 In Python, you can use the [b]print [/b]function to produce output. This displays a textual representation of something to the screen.[code format="py" codeId="285"]>>> [b]print[/b](1 + 1)
2
>>> [b]print[/b]("Hello\nWorld!")
Hello
World![/code]
[note]When a string is printed, the quotes around it are not displayed.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blank to prompt for user input.
[!raw!]
>>> {0}("Enter a number:")
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Input[/h1]

To get input from the user in Python, you can use the intuitively named [b]input[/b] function. 
The function prompts the user for input, and returns what they enter as a string (with the contents automatically escaped).[code format="raw" codeId="945"]>>> [b]input[/b]("Enter something please: ")
[b]Enter something please: This is what\nthe user enters![/b]

'This is what\\nthe user enters!'[/code]
[note]The [b]print [/b]and [b]input [/b]functions aren't very useful at the Python console, which automatically does input and output. However, they are very useful in actual programs.[/note]
